docs.snippet: THE skycaps have disappeared from many of the nation's airports, along with those sophisticated electronic check-in machines that spat out a boarding pass and made it possible to breeze from the curb to the gate without talking to anyone.    Gift ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE skycaps have disappeared from many of the nation's airports, along with those sophisticated electronic check-in machines that spat out a boarding pass and made it possible to breeze from the curb to the gate without talking to anyone. Gift shops in many airports have stopped selling scissors, nail clippers, eyeglass-repair kits and anything else that might be converted into a weapon. On board, there are no more steak knives in first class. And perhaps that's just as well, since on many flights, there is no more steak. Meal service is being curtailed or abandoned by airlines that warn they are being forced to the brink of bankruptcy by the collapse in passenger traffic.
docs.abstract: Philip Shenon travel article describes changes in rules of air travel and airport safety since September 11 terrorist attacks; what once seemed routine mode of travel now seems dangerous and federal government and US airlines have responded by tightening security; some new security measures described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The state’s latest attempt at denying women reproductive freedom was temporarily blocked by a federal judge.
docs.abstract: Editorial applauds Federal Judge Daniel Jordan III for temporarily blocking enforcement of a Mississippi law that would effectively end all abortions in the state; urges Jordan to extend the temporary injunction and then rule to permanently block the campaign to deny women in the state reproductive freedoms.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The United States will place sharp travel restrictions on Soviet diplomats and representatives in this country early next week. At or about that time seven other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, who maintai...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The United States will place sharp travel restrictions on Soviet diplomats and representatives in this country early next week. At or about that time seven other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, who maintain diplomatic missions in Moscow, also will impose travel limitations on the Russians.

headline.main: U. S. TRAVEL CURBS ON RUSSIANS NEAR; Retaliation Against Moscow Aides Due Early This Week -- Others in NATO Will Act

docs.snippet: Been to the Tokelau Islands in the South Pacific? To Tristan da Cunha in the South Atlantic? What about Ogasawara-gunto in the Bonin Islands off Japan or the Bismarck Archipelago in the Southwest Pacific?   If the answer is yes, perhaps a membersh...
docs.lead_paragraph: Been to the Tokelau Islands in the South Pacific? To Tristan da Cunha in the South Atlantic? What about Ogasawara-gunto in the Bonin Islands off Japan or the Bismarck Archipelago in the Southwest Pacific? If the answer is yes, perhaps a membership in the Travelers' Century Club is in the offing. The club regards itself as one of the world's most exclusive because eligibility is limited to individuals who have visited 100 or more countries or island groups. Membership now stands at something beyond 600, but affiliation of sorts is open to those who have yet to achieve the century mark, which is admittedly difficult. For example, someone who has been to the United States, Canada and Mexico, to all the countries in Europe and to every country in South America has a total of 55, and, tossing in Oriental countries and others bordering the Mediterranean, the club puts the total at 89, still 11 short of qualification.

byline.original: Qualify for Club, By Visiting 100 Countries

byline.original: By JAY WALZ Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: To the Editor: Did Betsy Wade and I really go on the same American Family Cruise trip, and the same week, no less? ("Boys and Girls Together," April 10).   The cruise itself had many problems; children of all ages ran everywhere unsupervised. The ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Did Betsy Wade and I really go on the same American Family Cruise trip, and the same week, no less? ("Boys and Girls Together," April 10). The cruise itself had many problems; children of all ages ran everywhere unsupervised. The table next to ours had only children under about the age of 12 who were so loud that we could often not hear ourselves speak. The roller-skating meant passengers walked about at their peril. On an island excursion, my daughter and another passenger signed up for wind-surfing; my daughter ended up alone far from shore without her instructor and made it back only because she is such a strong swimmer.
